Award.AwardTitle: New Nonheme Iron Complexes for Nitric Oxide Reactivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The support provided by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division allows the research group of Professor David Goldberg in the Department of Chemistry at Johns Hopkins University to develop a new family of iron-containing compounds that activating nitrogen oxide or NOx species. The chemical changes of NOx species, including nitric oxide and its related molecules nitroxyl (HNO) and nitrite ion (NO2-), are critically important for a number of biochemical processes, including cell signaling, immune response, and therapeutic strategies. Nitric oxide is a key neurotransmitter in the brain and throughout the nervous system. There is also significant current interest in the role of HNO in the brain and how it is generated. In this project, Dr. Goldberg and his group construct new iron complexes that bind and react with NOx species. They carry out chemical changes on these molecules related to enzymatic processes. Graduate and undergraduate students are educated and trained in experimental chemical science. An outreach program for students underrepresented in science involving a Baltimore City high school is underway.

The synthesis of a new family of polydentate ligands and their related nonheme iron complexes is under investigation for the binding and activation of NOx species. The oxidative and reductive transformations of several forms of NOx are examined. The observed reactivity is related to enzymatic processes that occur in iron-containing nitric oxide reductases, nitrite reductases, and nitric oxide dioxygenases. In addition, the fundamental reactivity of NOx species, which are potent signaling molecules, is important to a range of processes in the brain and nervous system. Through ligand design, the steric and electronic properties at the metal center are controlled. The study of these complexes may provide insights regarding how structure relates to function in iron-mediated NOx reactivity. Specific efforts will focus on the reduction of NO to NO-/HNO and N2O, the oxidation of NO to NO2- and NO3-, and the reduction of nitrite (NO2-) by biologically relevant reducing agents. The educational plans include an outreach program to a local Baltimore City high school that provides a hands-on laboratory experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the chemistry of nitric oxide in combination with iron centers in biologically relevant environments. Nitric oxide (NO) is a small, gaseous molecule that plays a critical role in a number of biological processes, including the transmission of chemical signals between cells, as well as for defense against invading organisms. Related molecules including nitroxyl (HNO), a reduced form of NO, and nitrite (NO2-), an oxidized form of NO. These molecules also have important functions in biology. These species tend to interact with naturally occurring metal ions such as iron (Fe), and it is the nature of this interaction which was studied in this project. New Fe(NO) species were synthesized, and their molecular structures and properties were assessed. These findings provided new knowledge regarding how these key species may interact in a biological setting. For example, it was found that a rationally designed, new compound containing a single iron center was capable of converting NO to nitrous oxide (N2O), which helps in understanding how the same conversion can occur in an iron-containing enzyme known as nitric oxide reductase, which facilitates the same process. Other major findings include obtaining new knowledge on how nitroxyl donor molecules such as piloty's acid, which are used in biochemical studies and medical applications, interact with an iron atom housed in a synthetic organic molecule that mimics key aspects of a biological environment. These studies have also led to new, fundamental knowledge on methods for the design and preparation of new iron compounds, as well as how synthetic chemists can tune the environment of metal ions to mediate the selective oxidative and reductive transformations of small molecules such as NO and related species.

Graduate and undergraduate students who were involved with this project were trained in modern methods of experimental chemical science, with a focus on bioinorganic chemistry, synthesis, modern chemical instrumentation, reactivity, and mechanism. The training environment for these students also included collaborative efforts with other researchers at Oregon Health & Science University, Cornell University, University of Erlangen, Germany; University of Otago, New Zealand and The University of Manchester, UK. An outreach workshop program for students at a local Baltimore City public high school involved a chemical laboratory experience, as well as an introduction to research scientists and state-of-the-art research facilities at Johns Hopkins University.


Last Modified: 01/26/2021
Modified by: David P Goldberg

These species tend to interact with naturally occurring metal ions such as iron (Fe), and it is the nature of this interaction which was studied in this project. New Fe(NO) species were synthesized, and their molecular structures and properties were assessed. These findings provided new knowledge regarding how these key species may interact in a biological setting. For example, it was found that a rationally designed, new compound containing a single iron center was capable of converting NO to nitrous oxide (N2O), which helps in understanding how the same conversion can occur in an iron-containing enzyme known as nitric oxide reductase, which facilitates the same process. Other major findings include obtaining new knowledge on how nitroxyl donor molecules such as piloty's acid, which are used in biochemical studies and medical applications, interact with an iron atom housed in a synthetic organic molecule that mimics key aspects of a biological environment. These studies have also led to new, fundamental knowledge on methods for the design and preparation of new iron compounds, as well as how synthetic chemists can tune the environment of metal ions to mediate the selective oxidative and reductive transformations of small molecules such as NO and related species. Graduate and undergraduate students who were involved with this project were trained in modern methods of experimental chemical science, with a focus on bioinorganic chemistry, synthesis, modern chemical instrumentation, reactivity, and mechanism. The training environment for these students also included collaborative efforts with other researchers at Oregon Health & Science University, Cornell University, University of Erlangen, Germany; University of Otago, New Zealand and The University of Manchester, UK. An outreach workshop program for students at a local Baltimore City public high school involved a chemical laboratory experience, as well as an introduction to research scientists and state-of-the-art research facilities at Johns Hopkins University.
